case_vignette: A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of palpitations and loose stools. She has had a 2.3-kg (5-lb) weight loss over the past month. She has had no change in appetite. She has no history of serious illness. She works in accounting and has been under more stress than usual lately. She takes no medications. She appears pale. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 126/78 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bilateral hand tremor with outstretched arms and a palpable thyroid nodule in the left lobe. Serum laboratory studies show a thyroid stimulating hormone level of 0.03 μU/mL and a thyroxine level of 28 μg/dL. A radioactive iodine uptake scan shows enhancement in a 3-cm encapsulated nodule in the lower left lobe with decreased uptake in the remaining gland.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Based on your symptoms and medical history, I would like to perform the following tests to help rule out any underlying conditions that may be causing your heart palpitations:

1. Electrocardiogram (ECG): This test will measure the electrical activity of your heart and check for any abnormal rhythms or patterns.
2. Holter monitor: This test will record your heart's electrical activity over a 24-hour period to detect any irregular rhythms or patterns.
3. Event monitor: This test will record your heart's electrical activity over a longer period of time, usually several days, to detect any irregular rhythms or patterns.
4. Stress test: This test will check how your heart functions during physical activity and help determine if your heart is able to handle stress.
5. Echocardiogram: This test will use sound waves to create images of your heart and check for any structural problems or abnormalities.

Once the tests are complete, I will be able to provide you with a more accurate diagnosis and recommend the appropriate treatment.
